Tech |accessdate=May 15, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160531170505/https://www.yahoo.com/tech/happy-birthday-super-mario-181332681.html?nf=1 |archivedate=May 31, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} In 2010, Nintendo released special red variants of the [[Wii]] and [[Nintendo DSi XL]] consoles in re-packaged, Mario-themed limited edition bundles as part of the 25th anniversary of the game's original release.{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2010/10/21/red-wii-and-dsi-xl-bundles-wii-remote-plus-and-flingsmash-in-n/ |date=October 21, 2010 |title=Red Wii and DSi XL bundles, Wii Remote Plus, and FlingSmash in North America Nov. 7 |first=JC |last=Fletcher |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |accessdate=February 6, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170828052549/https://www.engadget.com/2010/10/21/red-wii-and-dsi-xl-bundles-wii-remote-plus-and-flingsmash-in-n/ |archivedate=August 28, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} To celebrate the series' 30th anniversary, Nintendo released ''[[Super Mario Maker]]'', a game for the [[Wii U]] which allows players to create custom platforming stages using assets from ''Super Mario'' games and in the style of ''Super Mario Bros.'' along with other styles based around different games in the series.{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gaming/what-to-play/super-mario-30th-anniversary-party/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-02-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180221100046/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/gaming/what-to-play/super-mario-30th-anniversary-party/ |archivedate=February 21, 2018 |df=mdy-all }} The game's success helped to push Mario as an American [[cultural icon]]; in 1990, a study taken in North America suggested that more children in the United States were familiar with Mario than they were with [[Mickey Mouse]], another popular media character.{{cite newspaper |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1993-05-18/features/1993138174_1_mario-nintendo-mickey-mouse |title=How Mario Conquered America |first=James |last=Coates |date=May 18, 1993 |work=[[The Chicago Tribune]] |accessdate=February 7, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20151123103152/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1993-05-18/features/1993138174_1_mario-nintendo-mickey-mouse |archivedate=November 23, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} The game's musical score composed by Koji Kondo, particularly the game's "overworld" theme, has also become a prevalent aspect of popular culture, with the latter theme being featured in nearly every single ''Super Mario'' game.{{cite web |url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/9bgkyv/exclusive-read-an-excerpt-from-the-new-33-13-book-on-koji-kondos-super-mario-bros-soundtrack-900 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-02-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208004749/https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/9bgkyv/exclusive-read-an-excerpt-from-the-new-33-13-book-on-koji-kondos-super-mario-bros-soundtrack-900 |archivedate=February 8, 2018 |df=mdy-all }} Alongside the NES platform as a whole, ''Super Mario Bros.'' is often credited for having resurrected the [[video game industry]] after it had [[Video game crash of 1983|experienced a market crash in 1983]].{{cite web |url=http://top100.ign.com/2005/001-010.html |title=IGN's Top 100 Games |work=ign.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YQvH6xHh?url=http://top100.ign.com/2005/001-010.html |archivedate=May 11, 2015 |df=mdy-all |access-date=February 13, 2018 }} ''Super Mario Bros.'' and its sequels inspired various projects in media; the 1986 [[anime]] film ''[[Super Mario Bros.: The Great Mission to Rescue Princess Peach!]]'' is acknowledged as one of the first feature-length films to be based directly off of a video game.{{cite book |title=Guinness Book of World Records 2015: Gamer's Edition |publisher=Guinness World Records |date=November 14, 2014 |page=179 |isbn=1908843667}} A [[live-action]] [[Super Mario Bros. (film)|film based on the game]] was released theatrically in 1993, starring [[Bob Hoskins]] and [[John Leguizamo]] as Mario and Luigi, respectively. An American [[animated series|animated television series]] titled ''[[The Super Mario Bros. Super Show!]]'' ran from 1989 to 1990, starring [[professional wrestler]] [[Lou Albano]] as Mario and [[Danny Wells]] as Luigi. An animated film based on the series created by [[Illumination Entertainment]] is currently in production.{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/1/31/16958064/nintendo-mario-movie-illumination-minions |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-02-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180221100054/https://www.theverge.com/2018/1/31/16958064/nintendo-mario-movie-illumination-minions |archivedate=February 21, 2018 |df=mdy-all }} In the [[United States Supreme Court]] case ''[[Brown v. Entertainment Merchants Association]]'', the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] submitted an ''amicus'' brief which supported the overturn a law which would ban violent video games in the state of [[California]]. The brief cited social research that declared ''Super Mario Bros'', among several others, to contain cartoon violence similar to that found in children's programs such as [[Mighty Mouse]] and [[Wile E. Coyote and the Road Runner|Road Runner]] that garnered little negative reaction from the public.{{cite web |last=Hoffman |first=Gene |title=How the Wrong Decision in ''Schwarzenegger v. EMA'' Could Cripple Video Game Innovation |work=Xconomy.com |date=September 27, 2010 |accessdate=September 27, 2010 |url=http://www.xconomy.com/san-francisco/2010/09/27/how-the-wrong-decision-in-schwarzenegger-v-ema-could-cripple-video-game-innovation/ |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100930150915/http://www.xconomy.com/san-francisco/2010/09/27/how-the-wrong-decision-in-schwarzenegger-v-ema-could-cripple-video-game-innovation/ |archivedate=September 30, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |last=Schwarzenegger |first=Arnold |authorlink=Arnold Schwarzenegger |date=September 2010 |title=Brief of the Progress & Freedom Foundation and the Electronic Frontier Foundation as ''Amici Curiae'' in Support of Respondents |url=https://www.eff.org/files/filenode/schwarzenegger_v/EFFPFFamicus.pdf |accessdate=October 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101009033941/http://www.eff.org/files/filenode/schwarzenegger_v/EFFPFFamicus.pdf |archivedate=October 9, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} Video game developer [[Yuji Naka]] has cited ''Super Mario Bros.'' as a large inspiration towards the concept for the immensely successful 1991 [[Sega Genesis]] game, ''[[Sonic the Hedgehog (1991 video game)|Sonic the Hedgehog]]''; according to Naka, the general idea for the game first materialized when he was playing through game and trying to beat the game’s first level as quickly as possible, and thought about the concept of a platformer based around moving as fast as possible. ''Super Mario Bros.'' has served as inspiration for several [[fangame]]s. In 2009, developer SwingSwing released ''[[Tuper Tario Tros]]'', a game which combines elements of ''Super Mario Bros.'' with ''[[Tetris]]''.{{cite web|last=McWhertor|first=Michael|title=Tuper Tario Tros. Puts A Little Tetris In Your Mushroom Kingdom|url=http://kotaku.com/5436334/tuper-tario-tros-puts-a-little-tetris-in-your-mushroom-kingdom|publisher=[[Kotaku]]|accessdate=20 January 2014|date=29 December 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201185620/http://kotaku.com/5436334/tuper-tario-tros-puts-a-little-tetris-in-your-mushroom-kingdom|archivedate=1 February 2014|df=}}{{cite web|last=Donlan|first=Chris|title=Tuper Tario Tros.|url=http://www.edge-online.com/features/friday-game-tuper-tario-tros|work=Edge|accessdate=20 January 2014|date=2 September 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120328080922/http://www.edge-online.com/features/friday-game-tuper-tario-tros |archivedate=March 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes}} ''[[Super Mario Bros. Crossover]]'', a PC fangame developed by Jay Pavlina and released in 2010 as a free browser-based game, is a full recreation of ''Super Mario Bros.'' that allows the player to alternatively control various other characters from Nintendo games, including [[Mega Man (character)|Mega Man]], [[Link (character)|Link]] from ''[[The Legend of Zelda]]'', [[Samus]] from ''[[Metroid]]'', and [[Simon Belmont]] from ''[[Castlevania]]''.{{cite web|url=https://gamerant.com/super-mario-bros-crossover-game-benk-19406/|title=GR Pick: Super Mario Bros. Crossover Game|author=|date=April 29, 2010|website=gamerant.com}} ''[[Mari0]]'', released in December 2012, combines elements of the game with that of [[Portal (video game)|Portal]] by giving Mario a portal gun which he can use to seamlessly transport from one area of a level to another,{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5835600/mari0-puts-a-portal-gun-in-super-mario-bros|title=Mari0 Is What Happens When Mario Gets a Portal Gun|first=Michael|last=McWhertor|date=|website=kotaku.com}} while ''[[Full Screen Mario]]'' (2013) adds a [[level editor]].{{cite web |last1=Whitehead |first1=Thomas |title=Full Screen Mario Web Game Closed Down Following Nintendo's Copyright Complaint |url=http://www.nintendolife.com/news/2013/11/full_screen_mario_web_game_closed_down_following_nintendos_copyright_complaint |website=[[Nintendo Life]] |accessdate=October 10, 2018 |date=November 11, 2013}} In 2015, game designer Josh Millard released ''[[Ennuigi]]'', a [[metafiction]]al [[fangame]] with commentary on the original game which relates to Luigi's inability to come to terms with the game's overall lack of narrative.{{cite web |first1=Jennifer |last1=Billock |url=http://www.avclub.com/article/one-mario-bros-has-existential-crisis-new-game-enn-223496 |title=One of the Mario Bros. has an existential crisis in the new game Ennuigi |work=[[The A.V. Club]] |publisher=The Onion |date=August 6, 2015 |accessdate=August 31, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160831000522/http://www.avclub.com/article/one-mario-bros-has-existential-crisis-new-game-enn-223496 |archivedate=August 31, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |first1=Emanuel |last1=Maiberg |url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/uh-oh-luigi-read-some-derrida-and-now-hes-ennuigi |title=Uh Oh, Luigi Read Some Derrida and Now He's 'Ennuigi' |work=Motherboard |publisher=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]] |date=August 17, 2015 |accessdate=August 31, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161010135753/http://motherboard.vice.com/read/uh-oh-luigi-read-some-derrida-and-now-hes-ennuigi |archivedate=October 10, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |first1=Martin |last1=Schneider |url=http://dangerousminds.net/comments/ennuigi_nintendo_for_pretentious_existentialists |title='Ennuigi': Nintendo for pretentious existentialists |work=Dangerous Minds |date=August 6, 2015 |accessdate=August 31, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160903010105/http://dangerousminds.net/comments/ennuigi_nintendo_for_pretentious_existentialists |archivedate=September 3, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |first1=Steven |last1=Messner |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/ennuigi-mario-flash-game/ |title=In Ennuigi you play a depressed, chain-smoking Luigi who's lost all hope |work=[[PC Gamer]] |publisher=[[Future plc]] |date=August 29, 2016 |accessdate=August 31, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160901124530/http://www.pcgamer.com/ennuigi-mario-flash-game/ |archivedate=September 1, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} ==Notes== {{notelist}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Prone to spam|date=March 2013}} {{Z148}} * {{cite web |url=http://register.nintendo.com/gamemini?gameid=9b8f1efe-3ac4-4d81-9a17-e7458e1891a7 |title=''Super Mario Bros.'' for Game Boy Advance |work=[[Nintendo.com]] |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930005808/http://www.nintendo.com/gamemini?gameid=9b8f1efe-3ac4-4d81-9a17-e7458e1891a7}} * {{cite web |url=http://register.nintendo.com/gamemini?gameid=3AhiHlPhEtLc5rGACE1dxueM0y5QDqCZ |title=''Super Mario Bros.'' for Virtual Console |work=[[Nintendo.com]] |archivedate=December 30, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071230093936/http://register.nintendo.com/gamemini?gameid=3AhiHlPhEtLc5rGACE1dxueM0y5QDqCZ}} * [https://www.nintendo.co.jp/n02/dmg/ahyj/index.html Official Nintendo Japan ''Super Mario Bros. Deluxe'' site] {{Super Mario}} {{Shigeru Miyamoto}} {{Portal bar|Mario|Nintendo|Video Games|1980s|Japan}} [[Category:1985 video games]] [[Category:Arcade games]] [[Category:Famicom Disk System games]] [[Category:Game & Watch games]] [[Category:Game Boy Advance games]] [[Category:Game Boy Color games]] [[Category:Mario platform games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:NEC PC-8801 games]] [[Category:Nintendo Entertainment Analysis and Development games]] [[Category:Nintendo Entertainment System games]] [[Category:Nintendo Vs. Series games]] [[Category:PlayChoice-10 games]] [[Category:Sharp X1 games]] [[Category:Side-scrolling platform games]] [[Category:Fiction about size change]] [[Category:Video games scored by Koji Kondo]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games directed by Shigeru Miyamoto]] [[Category:Video games produced by Shigeru Miyamoto]] [[Category:Virtual Console games for Nintendo 3DS]] [[Category:Virtual Console games for Wii]] [[Category:Virtual Console games for Wii U]] [[Category:Virtual Console games]]

page.title: The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Infobox video game |title=The Legend of Zelda:
Link's Awakening |image=Links Awakening box.jpg |alt=A sword stands over a shield, and goes through the letter "Z" in the title "The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening". |caption=European Game Boy box art |developer=[[Nintendo Entertainment Analysis & Development]] |publisher=[[Nintendo]] |director=[[Takashi Tezuka]] |producer=[[Shigeru Miyamoto]] |designer= |programmer={{plainlist| *Takamitsu Kuzuhara *Kazuaki Morita }} |artist=[[Yoichi Kotabe]] |writer={{plainlist| *[[Yoshiaki Koizumi]] *[[Kensuke Tanabe]] }} |composer={{plainlist| *Kozue Ishikawa }} |series=''[[The Legend of Zelda]]'' |platforms=[[Game Boy]], [[Game Boy Color]] |released='''Game Boy'''
{{Video game release|JP|June 6, 1993{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/n02/dmg/zlj/index.html|script-title=ja:ゼルダの伝説 夢をみる島|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo Co., Ltd]]|accessdate=March 26, 2009}}|NA|August 1993{{cite web |url=https://www.nintendo.com/consumer/gameslist/manuals/dmg_games.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vo8Bg2rI?url=http://www.nintendo.com/consumer/gameslist/manuals/dmg_games.pdf |archivedate=January 17, 2011 |title=Game Boy (original) Games |publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc]] |accessdate=January 17, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}|EU|November 18, or December 1993{{cite web |url=https://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/news/iwata/iwata_asks_-_zelda_handheld_history_15603_15604.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vo8HCTzQ?url=http://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/news/iwata/iwata_asks_-_zelda_handheld_history_15603_15604.html |archivedate=January 17, 2011 |title=Iwata Asks: Zelda Handheld History – Like an Afterschool Club |publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of Europe GmbH]] |accessdate=January 17, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}[http://www.mobygames.com/game/gameboy/legend-of-zelda-links-awakening/release-info The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening (1993) Game Boy release dates - MobyGames]: "Country: United Kingdom - Release Date: Nov 18, 1993"Mega Fun 11/1993 (German magazine; [http://www.kultboy.com/index.php?site=t&id=2616 Scan @ Kultboy.com]): "Erscheinungstermin: November" (Release date: November)}}'''Game Boy Color'''
{{Video game release|JP|December 12, 1998{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/n02/dmg/azlj/index.html|title=Zeldaの伝説 – Introduction|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080116182314/http://www.nintendo.co.jp/n02/dmg/azlj/index.html|archivedate=January 16, 2008|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo Co., Ltd]]|accessdate=January 17, 2011}}{{Video game release|NA|December 15, 1998{{cite web|url=http://members.aol.com/capscott/guide64/gb.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991009103912/http://members.aol.com/capscott/guide64/gb.htm|archivedate=October 9, 1999|title=Guide 64: Game Boy Release Schedule}}}}|EU|January 1, 1999{{cite web |url=https://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/games/gb/the_legend_of_zelda_links_awakening_dx.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5vpb0kyok?url=http://www.nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/games/gb/the_legend_of_zelda_links_awakening_dx.html |archivedate=January 18, 2011 |title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX |publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of Europe GmbH]] |accessdate=May 17, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}}} |genre=[[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]] |modes=[[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }} '''''The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening'''''{{efn|Known as {{nihongo|''Zeruda no Densetsu: Yume o Miru Shima''|ゼルダの伝説 夢をみる島||lit. The Legend of Zelda: The Dream Island}} in Japan.}} is a 1993 [[action-adventure game|action-adventure]] video game developed by [[Nintendo Entertainment Analysis & Development]] and published by [[Nintendo]] for the [[Game Boy]]. It is the fourth installment in ''[[The Legend of Zelda]]'' series, and the first for a [[handheld game console]]. ''Link's Awakening'' began as a port of the [[Super Nintendo Entertainment System|Super NES]] title ''[[The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past]]'', developed after-hours by Nintendo staff. It grew into an original project under the direction of [[Takashi Tezuka]], with a story and script created by [[Yoshiaki Koizumi]] and [[Kensuke Tanabe]]. It is one of the few ''Zelda'' games not to take place in the land of [[Universe of The Legend of Zelda#Hyrule|Hyrule]], and does not feature [[Princess Zelda]] or the [[Triforce]] relic. Instead, protagonist [[Link (The Legend of Zelda)|Link]] begins the game stranded on Koholint Island, a place guarded by a [[whale]]-like [[deity]] called the Wind Fish. Assuming the role of Link, the player fights monsters and solves puzzles while searching for eight musical instruments that will awaken the sleeping Wind Fish and allow him to escape from the island. ''Link's Awakening'' was critically and commercially successful. Critics praised the game's depth and number of features; complaints focused on its control scheme and monochrome graphics. An updated re-release titled '''''The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX'''''{{efn|Known in Japan as {{nihongo|''Zeruda no Densetsu: Yume o Miru Shima Derakkusu''|ゼルダの伝説 夢をみる島DX|pronounced as The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening Deluxe}}}} was released for the [[Game Boy Color]] in 1998 featuring color graphics, compatibility with the [[Game Boy Printer]], and an exclusive color-based dungeon. Together, the two versions of the game have sold more than six million units worldwide, and have appeared on multiple game publications' lists of the [[List of video games considered the best|best games of all time]]. ==Plot== ===Setting and characters=== Unlike most ''[[The Legend of Zelda]]'' titles, ''Link's Awakening'' is set outside the kingdom of [[Hyrule]]. It omits locations and characters from previous games, aside from protagonist Link and a passing mention of [[Princess Zelda]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gametrailers.com/full-episodes/lc60ui/gt-retrospectives-zelda-retrospective-part-2|title=Zelda Retrospective Part 2|date=October 20, 2006|website=[[GameTrailers]]|publisher=[[MTV Networks]]|accessdate=March 10, 2011}}{{cite video game|title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX|developer=[[Nintendo|Nintendo Co., Ltd]]|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc.]]|date=December 1, 1998|quote='''Marin:''' I thought you'd never wake up! You were tossing and turning... What? Zelda? No, my name's Marin!}} Instead, the game takes place entirely on Koholint Island, an isolated landmass cut off from the rest of the world. The island, though small, contains a large number of secrets and interconnected pathways.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gamespot/features/video/hist_zelda/page11.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051221112025/http://www.gamespot.com/gamespot/features/video/hist_zelda/page11.html|archivedate=December 21, 2005|title=History of Zelda|page=11|author1=Vestal, Andrew |author2=O'Neill, Cliff |author3=Shoemaker, Brad |website=[[GameSpot]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive Inc]]|accessdate=December 4, 2007}} In ''Link's Awakening'', the player is given advice and directions by [[non-player character]]s such as Ulrira, a shy old man who communicates with Link exclusively by telephone. The game contains [[cameo appearance]]s by characters from other Nintendo titles, such as [[Wart (character)|Wart]], [[Yoshi]], [[Kirby (character)|Kirby]], Dr. Wright (renamed Mr. Write) from the Super NES version of ''[[SimCity (1989 video game)|SimCity]]'', and the exiled prince Richard from ''[[Kaeru no Tame ni Kane wa Naru]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.uk/Iwata-Asks/Iwata-Asks-The-Legend-of-Zelda-Spirit-Tracks/Iwata-Asks-Zelda-Handheld-History-/2-Kirby-and-Chomps-in-Zelda/2-Kirby-and-Chomps-in-Zelda-233781.html|title=2. Kirby and Chomps in Zelda}}{{cite web |url=http://stars.ign.com/objects/920/920753.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wRjbQSmV?url=http://stars.ign.com/objects/920/920753.html |archivedate=February 12, 2011 |title=Prince Richard (Legend of Zelda) |website=[[IGN]] |publisher=IGN Entertainment, Inc |accessdate=December 3, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[Chomp (Mario)|Chomp]], an enemy from the [[Mario (franchise)|''Mario'' series]], was included after a programmer gave Link the ability to grab the creature and take it for a walk. Enemies from ''[[Super Mario Bros.]]'' such as [[List of recurring Mario franchise enemies#Goomba|Goombas]] also appear in underground side-scrolling sections; Link may land on top of them much as with ''Super Mario Bros.'', or he can attack them in the usual way: the two methods yield different bonuses. Director Takashi Tezuka said that the game's "freewheeling" development made ''Link's Awakening'' seem like a parody of ''The Legend of Zelda'' series. Certain characters in the game break the [[fourth wall]]; for example, little children inform the player of game mechanics such as saving, but admit that they do not understand the advice they are giving.{{cite video game|title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX|developer=[[Nintendo|Nintendo Co., Ltd]]|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc.]]|date=December 1, 1998|quote='''Kid''': Hey man! When you want to save, just push all the Buttons at once! ...Uh, don't ask me what that means, I'm just a kid!}} ===Plot=== After the events of [[The Legend of Zelda: Link to the Past|''Link to the Past'']],https://kotaku.com/breath-of-the-wild-gets-official-placement-on-the-zelda-1828141649 the hero [[Link (The Legend of Zelda)|Link]] travels by ship to other countries to train for further threats. A storm destroys his boat at sea, and he washes ashore on Koholint Island,{{cite video game|title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX|developer=[[Nintendo|Nintendo Co., Ltd]]|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc.]]|date=December 1, 1998|quote='''Marin''': You must still be a little woozy. You are on Koholint Island!}} where he is taken to the house of Tarin by his daughter Marin. She is fascinated by Link and the outside world, and tells Link wishfully that, if she were a seagull, she would leave and travel across the sea.{{cite video game|title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX|developer=[[Nintendo|Nintendo Co., Ltd]]|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc.]]|date=December 1, 1998|quote='''Marin''': If I was a seagull, I would fly as far as I could! I would fly to far away places and sing for many people! ...If I wish to the Wind Fish, I wonder if my dream will come true...}} After Link recovers his sword, a mysterious owl tells him that he must wake the Wind Fish, Koholint's guardian, in order to return home. The Wind Fish lies dreaming in a giant egg on top of Mt. Tamaranch, and can only be awakened by the eight Instruments of the Sirens. Link proceeds to explore a series of dungeons in order to recover the eight instruments. During his search for the sixth instrument, Link goes to the Ancient Ruins. There he finds a mural that details the reality of the island: that it is merely a dream world created by the Wind Fish.{{cite video game|title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX |developer=[[Nintendo|Nintendo Co., Ltd]]|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc.]]|date=December 1, 1998|quote="To the finder, the isle of Koholint is but an illusion... Human, monster, sea, sky... a scene on the lid of a sleeper's eye... Awake the dreamer, and Koholint will vanish much like a bubble on a needle... Cast-away, you should know the truth!"}} After this revelation, the owl tells Link that this is only a rumor, and only the Wind Fish knows for certain whether it is true. Throughout Koholint Island, nightmare creatures attempt to obstruct Link's quest for the instruments, as they wish to rule the Wind Fish's dreamworld. After collecting all eight instruments from the eight dungeons across Koholint, Link climbs to the top of Mt. Tamaranch and plays the Ballad of the Wind Fish. This breaks open the egg in which the Wind Fish sleeps; Link enters and confronts the last evil being, a Nightmare that takes the form of [[Ganon]] and other enemies from Link's past.{{cite web|url=http://www.gametrailers.com/full-episodes/ln0wxo/gt-retrospectives-zelda-retrospective-part-6|title=Zelda Retrospective Part 6|date=November 20, 2006|website=[[GameTrailers]]|publisher=[[MTV Networks]]|accessdate=March 10, 2011}} Its final transformation is "DethI", a cyclopean, dual-tentacled Shadow.{{cite book|title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening – Nintendo Player's Guide|year=1994|page=84|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc]]}}{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19980224202702/http://www.nintendo.com/gb/zelda/boss9.html |url=https://www.nintendo.com/gb/zelda/boss9.html |archivedate=February 24, 1998 |title=Strategy – Bosses of the Egg |publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc]] |deadurl=yes |df= }} After Link defeats DethI, the owl reveals itself to be the Wind Fish's spirit, and the Wind Fish confirms that Koholint is all his dream. When Link plays the Ballad of the Wind Fish again, he and the Wind Fish awaken; Koholint Island and all its inhabitants slowly disappear.{{cite video game|title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX|developer=[[Nintendo|Nintendo Co., Ltd]]|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc.]]|date=December 1, 1998|quote='''Wind Fish''': But, verily, it be the nature of dreams to end! When I dost awaken, Koholint will be gone...}} Link finds himself lying on driftwood in the middle of the ocean, with the Wind Fish flying overhead. If the player did not lose any lives during the game, Marin is shown flying after the ending credits finish{{cite web|url=http://www.zelda.com/universe/game/awakening/faq.jsp|title=Link's Awakening – Frequently Asked Questions|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716143941/http://zelda.com/universe/game/awakening/faq.jsp|archivedate=July 16, 2011}} - she is shown in the form of a winged woman when played in the original black and white format, while she takes the form of a seagull if played with color in the DX version. ==Gameplay== [[File:ZeldaLA-DX comparison.png|thumb|left|The protagonist, Link, battles an enemy in a castle. The bottom portion of the screen displays [[Hyrule#Currency|rupees]], equipped items, and the character's [[Health (game mechanic)|health]] (represented by hearts). The right half of the image depicts the graphics of the original game, while the left shows the color graphics of the ''DX'' edition.|alt=In a castle, a boy in a green suit unsheats his sword against a knight in armor.]] Like most games in ''The Legend of Zelda'' series, ''Link's Awakening'' is an [[action-adventure game]] focused on exploration and combat. The majority of the game takes place from an overhead perspective. The player traverses the [[overworld]] of Koholint Island while fighting monsters and exploring underground dungeons. Dungeons steadily become larger and more difficult, and feature "Nightmare" [[Boss (video games)|boss]] characters that the player must defeat, taking different forms in each dungeon, and getting harder to defeat each time. Success earns the player heart containers, which increase the amount of damage the [[player character]] can survive; when all of the player's heart containers have been emptied, the game restarts at the last doorway entered by the character. Defeating a Nightmare also earns the player one of the eight instruments necessary to complete the game.{{Cite book|title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening Instruction Booklet|pages=9–28|date=August 1993|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc]]}} ''Link's Awakening'' was the first overhead-perspective ''Zelda'' game to allow Link to jump; this enables [[side-scrolling video game|sidescrolling]] sequences similar to those in the earlier ''[[Zelda II: The Adventure of Link]]''. Players can expand their abilities with [[Item (game)|items]], which are discovered in dungeons and through character interactions. Certain items grant access to previously inaccessible areas, and are needed to enter and complete dungeons. In addition to the main quest, ''Link's Awakening'' contains side-missions and diversions. Collectible "secret seashells" are hidden throughout the game; when twenty of these are found, the player can receive a powerful sword that fires energy beams when the player character is at full health, similar to the sword in the original ''[[The Legend of Zelda (video game)|The Legend of Zelda]]''. ''Link's Awakening'' is the first ''Zelda'' game to include a trading sequence [[minigame]]: the player may give a certain item to a character, who in turn gives the player another item to trade with someone else. It is also the first game in the ''Zelda'' series in which both the [[Game Boy#Features|A and B buttons]] may be assigned to a variety of items, which enables more varied puzzles and item combinations. Other series elements originating in ''Link's Awakening'' include fishing, and learning special songs on an [[ocarina]]; the latter mechanic is central to the next ''Zelda'' game released, ''[[The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time|Ocarina of Time]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/gamespot/features/video/hist_zelda/page13.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20031016020629/http://www.gamespot.com/gamespot/features/video/hist_zelda/page13.html|archivedate=October 16, 2003|title=History of Zelda|page=13|author1=Vestal, Andrew |author2=O'Neill, Cliff |author3=Shoemaker, Brad |website=[[GameSpot]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive Inc]]|accessdate=December 4, 2007}}{{clear}} ==Development== ''Link's Awakening'' began as an unsanctioned side project; programmer Kazuaki Morita created a ''Zelda''-like game with one of the first [[Game Boy]] [[development kit]]s, and used it to experiment with the platform's capabilities. Other staff members of the [[Nintendo Entertainment Analysis and Development]] division joined him [[wikt:after hours|after-hours]], and worked on the game in what seemed to them like an "afterschool club". The results of these experiments with the Game Boy started to look promising, and following the 1991 release of the Super NES video game ''[[The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past]]'', director [[Takashi Tezuka]] asked permission to develop a handheld ''Zelda'' title; he intended it to be a [[Video game porting|port]] of ''A Link to the Past'', but it evolved into an original game. The majority of the team that had created ''A Link to the Past'' was reassembled to advance this new project. Altogether, it took them one and a half years to develop ''Link's Awakening''.{{cite book|title=Nintendo Official Guide Book – The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening|chapter=「ゼルダの伝説 夢をみる島」開発スタッフ名鑑|language=Japanese|pages=120–124|date=July 1993|isbn=978-4-09-102448-0|publisher=[[Shogakukan|Shogakukan Inc]]}} [[File:Yoshiaki Koizumi 2007.jpg|thumb|upright|Designer Yoshiaki Koizumi was in charge of the game's story, and conceived major plot points such as the dream world island setting.|alt=A long-haired man wearing a coat and a striped shirt.]] Tezuka recalled that the early free-form development of ''Link's Awakening'' resulted in the game's "unrestrained" contents, such as the unauthorized cameo appearances of characters from the ''Mario'' and ''Kirby'' series. ''A Link to the Past'' script writer [[Kensuke Tanabe]] joined the team early on, and came up with the basis of the story.{{cite book|title=ゲームボーイ＆ゲームボーイカラー 任天堂公式ガイドブック ゼルダの伝説 夢を見る島DX|chapter=開発スタッフアンケート|language=Japanese|pages=108–111|date=February 20, 1999|isbn=978-4-09-102679-8|publisher=[[Shogakukan|Shogakukan Inc]]}} Tezuka sought to make ''Link's Awakening'' a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]], and gave Tanabe instructions to omit common series elements such as [[Princess Zelda]], the [[Triforce]] relic, and the setting [[Hyrule]]. As a consequence, Tanabe proposed his game world idea of an island with an egg on top of a mountain. Later on, [[Yoshiaki Koizumi]], who had previously helped with the plot of ''A Link to the Past'', was brought into the team. Koizumi was responsible for the main story of ''Link's Awakening'', provided the idea of the island in a dream, and conceived the interactions with the villagers.{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2007/12/interview-super/|title=Interview: Super Mario Galaxy Director On Sneaking Stories Past Miyamoto|date=December 4, 2007|author=Kohler, Chris|website=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired: GameLife]]|publisher=[[Condé Nast Digital]]|accessdate=June 10, 2010}}{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208121619/http://www.next-gen.biz/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=8731&Itemid=2|archivedate=February 8, 2008|title=Interview: Nintendo's Unsung Star|url=http://www.next-gen.biz/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=8731&Itemid=2|date=February 6, 2008|website=[[Edge (magazine)|Next Generation]]|publisher=[[Future US, Inc.]]|accessdate=July 11, 2010}} ''Link's Awakening'' was described by series producer [[Eiji Aonuma]] as the first ''Zelda'' game with a proper plot, which he attributed to Koizumi's romanticism.{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.uk/Iwata-Asks/Iwata-Asks-The-Legend-of-Zelda-Spirit-Tracks/Iwata-Asks-Zelda-Handheld-History-/3-Make-All-Characters-Suspicious-Types/3-Make-All-Characters-Suspicious-Types-233845.html|title=Iwata Asks: The History of Handheld The Legend of Zelda Games – Make All the Characters Suspicious Types|date=January 2010|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc]]|accessdate=January 13, 2011}} Tezuka intended the game's world to have a similar feeling to the American television series ''[[Twin Peaks]]'', which, like ''Link's Awakening'', features characters in a small town. He suggested that the characters of ''Link's Awakening'' be written as "suspicious types", akin to those in ''Twin Peaks''—a theme which carried over into later ''Zelda'' titles. Tanabe created these "odd" characters; he was placed in charge of the subevents of the story, and wrote almost all of the character dialog, with the exception of the owl's and the Wind Fish's lines. Tanabe implemented a previous idea of the world ending when a massive egg breaks on top of a mountain; this idea was originally meant for ''A Link to the Past''. Tanabe really wanted to see this idea in a game and was able to implement it in ''Link's Awakening'' as the basic concept.{{cite web|url=http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/57137/features/monkey-men-talking-to-michael-kelbaugh-and-kensuke-tanabe/?page=1|title=Monkey Men: talking to Michael Kelbaugh and Kensuke Tanabe|date=February 19, 2014|author=Skrebels, Joe|website=[[Official Nintendo Magazine]]|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|accessdate=February 21, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306201732/http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/57137/features/monkey-men-talking-to-michael-kelbaugh-and-kensuke-tanabe/?page=1|archive-date=March 6, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Masanao Arimoto and [[Shigefumi Hino]] designed the game's characters, while [[Yoichi Kotabe]] served as illustrator.{{cite video game |title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX|developer=[[Nintendo|Nintendo Co., Ltd]]|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc.]]|date=December 1, 1998|scene=staff credits}} Save for the opening and the ending, all pictures in the game were drawn by Arimoto. Yasahisa Yamamura designed the dungeons, which included the conception of rooms and routes, as well as the placement of enemies. [[Shigeru Miyamoto]], who served as the producer of ''Link's Awakening'', did not provide creative input to the staff members. However, he participated as [[game testing|game tester]], and his opinions greatly influenced the latter half of the development. The music for ''Link's Awakening'' was composed by Minako Hamano and Kozue Ishikawa, for whom it was their first game project. [[Kazumi Totaka]] was responsible for the sound programming and all sound effects. As with most ''Zelda'' games, ''Link's Awakening'' includes a variation of the recurring overworld music;{{cite web|url=http://www.gametrailers.com/full-episodes/rdq37a/gt-retrospectives-zelda-retrospective-part-1|title=Zelda Retrospective Part 1|website=[[GameTrailers]]|publisher=[[MTV Networks]]|date=October 13, 2006|accessdate=March 10, 2011}} the Game Boy arrangement of this theme, titled "Field", was created by Ishikawa.{{cite web |url=http://www.ymm.co.jp/p/detail.php?code=GTP01085505&o=0#song |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5utxYs9Ef?url=http://www.ymm.co.jp/p/detail.php?code=GTP01085505&o=0#song |archivedate=December 11, 2010 |script-title=ja:ピアノソロ ゼルダの伝説シリーズ/スーパーベスト |date=May 26, 2010 |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Yamaha Corporation|Yamaha Music Media Corporation]] |deadurl=yes |df= }} The staff credits theme, "Yume o Miru Shima e" was later arranged for orchestra by [[Yuka Tsujiyoko]], and performed at the ''[[Orchestral Game Music Concerts|Orchestral Game Music Concert 3]]'' in 1993.{{cite AV media notes|title=[[Orchestral Game Music Concerts|Orchestral Game Music Concert 3]]|year=1993|publisher=[[Sony Records]]}} ''[[Super Smash Bros. Brawl]]'' includes a remix of the game's "Tal Tal Heights" theme.{{cite web|url=http://www.smashbros.com/en_us/music/music24_list.html|title=Smash Bros. Dojo!! – Full Song List with Secret Songs|publisher=[[Nintendo|Nintendo of America Inc]]|accessdate=April 9, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101032549/http://www.smashbros.com/en_us/music/music24_list.html|archivedate=November 1, 2012}} In an interview about the evolution of the ''Zelda'' series, Aonuma called ''Link's Awakening'' the "quintessential [[Isometric projection|isometric]] ''Zelda'' game".{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2004/03/26/gdc-2004-the-history-of-zelda|title=GDC 2004: The History of Zelda|date=March 25, 2004|website=[[IGN]]|publisher=IGN Entertainment, Inc |accessdate=February 4, 2008}} At another time, he stated that, had the game not come after ''A Link to the Past'', ''[[The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time|Ocarina of Time]]'' would have been very different. Several elements from ''Link's Awakening'' were re-used in later ''Zelda'' titles; for example, programmer Morita created a fishing minigame that reappeared in ''Ocarina of Time'', among others. Tanabe implemented a trading sequence; Tezuka compared it to the Japanese [[Straw Millionaire]] folktale, in which someone trades up from a piece of straw to something of greater value. This concept also appeared in most sequels. ===Releases=== [[File:Game Boy Printer.png|thumb|upright|The [[Game Boy Printer]] accessory was compatible with the ''DX'' release of ''Link's Awakening''. Players could print out certain screenshots obtained in the game.]] To support the North American release of ''Link's Awakening'', Nintendo sponsored a crosscountry train competition called the Zelda Whistle Stop Tour.{{cite news|title='Legend of Zelda' Still Growing|page=C1|date=August 20, 1993|author=Williamson, Matt|work=[[Rocky Mountain News]]}} The event, which lasted three days, allowed select players to test ''Link's Awakening'' in a timed race to complete the game.{{cite news|title=Riding the rails for Nintendo contest|page=B2|date=August 30, 1993|author=Bette, Harrison|work=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]}} The event was meant not only to showcase the game, but also the Game Boy's superior battery life and portability, the latter of which was critical to the accessibility of a portable ''Zelda'' title. The company-owned magazine ''[[Nintendo Power]]'' published a guide to the game's first three areas in its July 1993 issue.{{cite journal|journal=[[Nintendo Power]]|title='The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening' Guide|volume=1|issue=50|pages=57–66|date=July 1993}} In 1998, to promote the launch of the [[Game Boy Color]], Nintendo re-released ''Link's Awakening'' as ''The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX''. It features fully colorized graphics and is [[Backward compatibility|backward compatible]] with the original Game Boy. ''Link's Awakening DX'' contains a new optional dungeon, with unique enemies and puzzles based on color (due to this the dungeon cannot be accessed on the earlier non-color Game Boy models). After completing the dungeon, the player may choose to receive either a red or blue tunic, which increase attack and defense, respectively. The ''DX'' version also allows players to take photos after the player visits a camera shop, its owner will appear in certain locations throughout the game. A total of twelve photos can be taken, which may be viewed at the shop, or printed with the [[Game Boy Printer]] accessory.{{cite news|title=Mega Mirror; Win two Game Boy games|work=The Mirror|page=41|date=February 27, 1999}} For ''Link's Awakening DX'', Tezuka returned as project supervisor, with Yoshinori Tsuchiyama as the new director. Nobuo Matsumiya collaborated with Tsuchiyama on applying changes to the original script; for example, hint messages were added to the boss battles. For the new dungeon, Yuichi Ozaki created a musical piece based on Kondo's dungeon theme from the [[The Legend of Zelda (video game)|original ''The Legend of Zelda'']].{{cite web|url=http://www.rpgfan.com/reviews/zeldagb/Zelda_4DX.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327130032/http://www.rpgfan.com/reviews/zeldagb/Zelda_4DX.html|archivedate=March 27, 2009|title=Reviews – The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX|date=February 7, 2000|author=Musashi|publisher=RPGFan|accessdate=June 5, 2011}} In 2010, Nintendo announced that the ''DX'' version would be re-released on the [[Virtual Console]] of the [[Nintendo 3DS]],{{cite web|url=http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/20178/3ds-virtual-console-will-play-game-boy-games/|title=3DS Virtual Console Will Play Game Boy Games|date=September 26, 2010|author=Scullion, Chris|website=[[Official Nintendo Magazine]]|publisher=[[Future Publishing Limited]]|accessdate=December 4, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603174333/http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/20178/3ds-virtual-console-will-play-game-boy-games/|archive-date=June 3, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} and became available June 2011. In July 2013, ''Link's Awakening DX'' was offered as one of several Virtual Console games which "elite status" members of the North America [[Club Nintendo]] could redeem as a free gift.{{cite web|title=2013 Club Nintendo Elite Status Rewards Now Available|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/07/15/2013-club-nintendo-elite-status-rewards-now-available|date=July 15, 2013|author=Goldfarb, Andrew|publisher=[[IGN|IGN Entertainment, INC.]]|accessdate=July 16, 2013}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | GR = 89.82%
91.21% (''DX'') | Allgame = {{Rating|4.5|5}} (DX){{cite web|last=Williamson|first=Colin|title=Link's Awakening DX - Review|url=http://allgame.com/game.php?id=16048&tab=review|publisher=AllGame|accessdate=June 10, 2014}} | GSpot = 8.7/10 (''DX'') | IGN = 10/10 (''DX'') | NP = 4.18/5 | award1Pub = [[Nintendo Power]] | award1 = Graphics and Sound, Challenge, Play Control, Best Overall
56th Best Nintendo Game | award2Pub = [[IGN]] | award2 = Reader's 40th Best Game of all time
Staff's 78th Best Game of all time | award3Pub = [[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] | award3 = Best Game Boy Game of 1993
Editor's Choice Award (''DX'') }} ''Link's Awakening'' was critically acclaimed, and holds an average score of 90% on aggregate site [[GameRankings]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/gameboy/563277-the-legend-of-zelda-links-awakening/index.html|title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening for Game Boy|website=[[GameRankings]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive Inc]]|accessdate=July 16, 2007}} In a retrospective article, ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]'' writer Jeremy Parish called ''Link's Awakening'' the "best Game Boy game ever".{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/features/link-thousand-faces|title=Link of A Thousand Faces|date=November 15, 2006|author=Parish, Jeremy|website=[[1UP.com]]|publisher=[[UGO Entertainment, Inc]]|accessdate=March 10, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6F3ItVSdL?url=http://www.1up.com/features/link-thousand-faces|archivedate=March 12, 2013}} ''[[Game Informer]]''{{'}}s Ben Reeves called it the third best Game Boy game and called it influential.{{cite web|title=The 25 Best Game Boy Games Of All Time|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2011/06/24/the-25-best-game-boy-games-of-all-time.aspx|website=[[Game Informer]]|last=Reeves |first=Ben |date=June 24, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2013}} ''[[The Washington Post]]''{{'}}s Chip Carter declared that Nintendo had created a "legend that fits in the palm of your hand", and praised its portability and depth.{{cite news|author=Carter, Chip|title=Nintendo Creates Legend That Fits in Your Hand|work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=August 4, 1993}} An Jōkiri of ITMedia echoed similar comments.{{cite web|url=http://gamez.itmedia.co.jp/games/articles/0707/04/news003.html|script-title=ja:「ゼルダの伝説 夢幻の砂時計」レビュー|date=July 4, 2007|author=Joukiri, An|language=Japanese|website=ITmedia +D Games|publisher=ITmedia Inc|accessdate=March 8, 2011}} A writer for the ''[[Mainichi Shimbun]]'' enjoyed the game's music and story.{{cite web|url=http://mainichi.jp/enta/mantan/game/etc/library/gb/se/19930606gamlib014000000c.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090303192558/http://mainichi.jp/enta/mantan/game/etc/library/gb/se/19930606gamlib014000000c.html|archivedate=March 3, 2009|script-title=ja:ゲームクエスト(ライブラリ) – ゼルダの伝説 夢をみる島|language=Japanese|date=February 25, 2005|website=[[Mainichi Shimbun|Mainichi.jp]]|publisher=Mainichi Newspapers Co. Ltd|accessdate=February 8, 2008}} Multiple sources touted it as an excellent portable adventure for those without the time for more sophisticated games.{{cite news|title=Little Plumber Boy; Night and Day|page=33|date=December 19, 1993|author=Diamond, John|work=The Mail}}{{cite news|title=The Guardian Features Page|page=21|date=December 9, 1993|author=Hughes, Gwyn|work=[[The Guardian]]}} Complaints about the game included its monochrome graphics; certain critics believed that they made it difficult to discern the screen's contents,{{cite news|title=Nintendo's Game Boy on big screen|page=J2 (Citizen Section: Weekend Fun; Electronic Gaming)|date=August 4, 1994|author=Provick, Bill|work=[[The Ottawa Citizen]]}} and wished that the game was in color. Critic William Burrill dismissed the game's visuals as "Dim Boy graphics [that are] nothing to write home about".{{cite news|title=Plot is a bit cliched, but Rocket Knight game has big, bright graphics|page=E5|date=October 14, 1993|author=Burrill, William|work=The Gazette}} Both Carter and ''[[The Ottawa Citizen]]''{{'}}s Bill Provick found the two-button control scheme awkward, as they needed to switch items on almost every screen. ''[[The Vancouver Sun]]''{{'}}s Katherine Monk called the dialogue "stilted", but considered the rest of the game to be "ever-surprising".{{cite news|title=Zelda lives up to her legend|page=F23|date=May 6, 1999|author=Monk, Katherine|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]}} ''Link's Awakening DX'' also received positive reviews; based on ten media outlets, it holds an average score of 92% on Game Rankings.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/gbc/197769-the-legend-of-zelda-links-awakening-dx/index.html|title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX for Game Boy Color|website=[[GameRankings]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive Inc]]|accessdate=July 16, 2007}} [[IGN]]'s Adam Cleveland awarded the game a perfect score, and noted that "throughout the color-enhanced version of ''Zelda DX'', it can easily be inferred that Nintendo has reworked its magic to fit new standards", by adding new content while keeping the original game intact.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/1999/09/17/legend-of-zelda-links-awakening-dx|title=Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX – Game Boy Color Review|date=September 17, 1999|author=Cleveland, Adam |website=[[IGN]]|publisher=IGN Entertainment, Inc |accessdate=December 4, 2007}} Cameron Davis of [[GameSpot]] applauded the game's camera support and attention to detail in coloration and style,{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/the-legend-of-zelda-links-awakening-dx/reviews/legend-of-zelda-dx-review-2536223/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306145921/http://www.gamespot.com/the-legend-of-zelda-links-awakening-dx/reviews/legend-of-zelda-dx-review-2536223/ |archive-date=March 6, 2012|title=The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening DX Review|date=January 28, 2000|author=Davis, Cameron|website=[[GameSpot]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive Inc]]|accessdate=May 14, 2007}} while reviewers for the ''[[The Courier-Mail|Courier Mail]]'' believed that the camera added gameplay depth and allowed players to show off trophies.{{cite news|title=What's On; The Legend of Zelda DX|page=4|date=January 14, 1999|author=Wilson, A.|work=[[The Courier-Mail|Courier Mail]]}} ''The Daily Telegraph''{{'}}s Samantha Amjadali wrote that the addition of color made the game easier by reducing deaths caused by indistinct graphics.{{cite news|title=Game on|page=T6|date=May 20, 1999|author1=Amjadali, Samantha |author2=Scatena, Dino |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}} ''Total Games'' noted that the new content added little to the game, but found it addictive to play nonetheless.{{cite journal|journal=Total Games' Guide to the Game Boy Color|title=Zelda: Link's Awakening DX|page=16|year=1999|issue=2}} ''Link's Awakening'' sold well, and helped boost Game Boy sales 13 percent in 1993—making it one of Nintendo's most profitable years in North America up to that time.{{cite news|title=Video games master Nintendo forecasting a record sales year|page=D5|date=October 20, 1993|author=Smith, David|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]}} The game remained on bestseller lists for more than 90 months after release,{{cite news|title=Fun time for couch potatoes: Video game reviews|page=F6|date=November 19, 2000|author=Kelley, Malcom|work=[[National Post]]}} and went on to sell 3.83 million units by 2004. The ''DX'' version sold another 2.22 million units.{{cite web|url=http://www.rpgamer.com/news/japan/rp033104.html|title=Japandemonium – Xenogears vs. Tetris|date=March 31, 2004|author=Parton, Rob|publisher=RPGamer|accessdate=June 21, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6F3IwupJp?url=http://www.rpgamer.com/news/japan/rp033104.html|archivedate=March 12, 2013}} The game won several awards, including those in the Game Boy categories for Graphics and Sound, Challenge, Theme and Fun, Play Control, and Best Overall in the reader-chosen 1993 ''Nintendo Power'' Awards.{{cite journal|journal=[[Nintendo Power]]|title=Nester Awards Results|pages=54–57|volume=1|issue=60|date=May 1994}} It was awarded Best Game Boy Game of 1993 by ''Electronic Gaming Monthly''.{{cite journal|journal=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]|title=Electronic Gaming Monthly's Buyer's Guide|date=January 1994}} ''Nintendo Power'' later named it the fifty-sixth best Nintendo game,{{cite journal|journal=[[Nintendo Power]]|title=NP Top 200|volume=1|issue=200|pages=58–66|date=February 2006}} and, in August 2008, listed the ''DX'' version as the second best [[Game Boy]] or [[Game Boy Color]] game.{{cite journal|journal=[[Nintendo Power]]|title=Nintendo Power – The 20th Anniversary Issue!|issue=231|page=72|date=August 2008}} IGN's readers ranked it as the 40th best game of all time, while the staff placed it at 78th;{{cite web|url=http://uk.top100.ign.com/2006/031-040.html|title=Readers' Picks Top 100 Games: 31–40|year=2006|website=[[IGN]]|publisher=IGN Entertainment, Inc|accessdate=January 22, 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071226031926/http://uk.top100.ign.com/2006/031-040.html|archivedate=December 26, 2007}} the staff believed that, "while handheld spin-offs are generally considered the low point for game franchises, ''Link's Awakening'' proves that they can offer just as rich a gameplay experience as their console counterparts".{{cite web|url=http://uk.top100.ign.com/2007/ign_top_game_78.html|title=IGN Top 100 Games 2007 – 78. The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening|date=December 9, 2007|website=[[IGN]]|publisher=IGN Entertainment, Inc|accessdate=June 4, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926203931/http://uk.top100.ign.com/2007/ign_top_game_78.html|archivedate=September 26, 2011}} The game took 42nd place on the [[Guinness World Records]]' 2009 list of the top 50 most important and influential video games of all time.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/guinness-lists-top-50-games-of-all-time|title=Guinness lists top 50 games of all time|date=February 27, 2009|author=Gibson, Ellie|website=[[Eurogamer.net]]|publisher=Eurogamer Network Ltd|accessdate=May 17, 2009}} ==References== ;Citations {{Reflist|30em}} ;Notes {{notelist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://zelda.com/universe/game/awakening/}} {{The Legend of Zelda}} {{Portal bar|1990s|Japan|Nintendo|The Legend of Zelda|Video games}} {{featured article}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening, The}} [[Category:1993 video games]] [[Category:Dreams in fiction]] [[Category:Game Boy Color games]] [[Category:Game Boy games]] [[Category:Nintendo Entertainment Analysis and Development games]] [[Category:Single-player video games]] [[Category:The Legend of Zelda video games|Link's Awakening]] [[Category:Top-down video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Virtual Console games]] [[Category:Virtual Console games for Nintendo 3DS]] [[Category:Video games set on fictional islands]]

{{about|the 1988 Pixar film|the type of toy|tin toy}} {{Infobox film | name = Tin Toy | image = Tin Toy poster.jpg | caption = Poster for ''Tin Toy'' | alt = Poster for Tin Toy | director = [[John Lasseter]] | producer = [[William Reeves (animator)|William Reeves]] | story = John Lasseter | starring = | music = | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = [[Pixar]] | released = {{Film date|1988|8|2}} | runtime = 5 minutes | country = United States | language = | budget = $300,000 {{cite web|url=http://topmdi.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1804:steve-jobs-19-eng&catid=198:steve-jobs-english&Itemid=274|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426004952/http://topmdi.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1804:steve-jobs-19-eng&catid=198:steve-jobs-english&Itemid=274|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-04-26|title=Steve Jobs 19 [Eng]}} | gross = }} '''''Tin Toy''''' is a 1988 American [[computer-animated]] [[short film]] produced by [[Pixar]] and directed by [[John Lasseter]]. The short film, which runs five minutes, stars Tinny, a tin [[one-man-band]] toy, attempting to escape from Billy, a destructive baby. The third short film produced by the company's small animation division, it was a risky investment: due to low revenue produced by Pixar's main product, the [[Pixar Image Computer]], the company was under financial constraints. Lasseter pitched the concept for ''Tin Toy'' by storyboard to Pixar owner [[Steve Jobs]], who agreed to finance the short despite the company's struggles, which he kept alive with annual investment. The film was officially a test of the [[PhotoRealistic RenderMan]] software, and proved new challenges to the animation team, namely the difficult task of realistically animating Billy. ''Tin Toy'' later gained attention from [[Disney]], who sealed an agreement to create ''[[Toy Story]]'' starring [[Tom Hanks]] and [[Tim Allen]], which was primarily inspired by elements from ''Tin Toy''. The short premiered in a partially completed edit at the [[SIGGRAPH]] convention in August 1988 to a standing ovation from scientists and engineers. ''Tin Toy'' went on to claim Pixar's first Oscar with the 1988 [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film|Best Animated Short Film]], becoming the first [[computer-generated imagery|CGI]] film to win an Oscar. With the award, ''Tin Toy'' went far to establish computer animation as a legitimate artistic medium outside SIGGRAPH and the animation-festival film circuit. ''Tin Toy'' was selected for preservation in the United States [[National Film Registry]] by the [[Library of Congress]] as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" in 2003. ==Plot== The film takes place in one room and stars the toy of the title, a mechanical one-man band player named Tinny, and a baby named Billy. At first, Tinny is delighted at the prospect of being played with by Billy until he sees how destructive the baby can be. When Tinny tries to walk out of Billy's reach, the musical instruments on the toy's back play notes, attracting Billy's attention. Tinny begins to run, but is chased by Billy. Tinny soon finds cover under the couch, only to find that many other toys have also hidden themselves from Billy there since they are also afraid and have learned the same experience. While walking and trying to find Tinny and the other toys, Billy falls flat onto the floor and begins to cry. Tinny, feeling sorry for the baby, goes to the child to cheer him up. Billy stops crying upon seeing Tinny, cheers up, and grabs Tinny, but plays with him by shaking him, and finds the box Tinny was packaged in even more fun to play with. Mad, Tinny follows Billy around the room in an attempt to get his attention, but is still ignored, when the baby is instead happier playing with boxes and a shopping bag while some toys come out from the couch to play. ==Background== Pixar, purchased in 1986 by entrepreneur and former [[Apple Computer]] head [[Steve Jobs]], received many accolades for films produced by its small animation division, headed by animator John Lasseter. Lasseter's primary role, as defended to Jobs by company founders Edwin Catmull and Alvy Ray Smith, was to produce short films to promote the company's own Pixar Image Computers.Price, p. 89 The department was never meant to generate any revenue as far as Jobs was concerned, but after the release of two shorts, ''[[Luxo Jr.]]'' (1986) and ''[[Red's Dream]]'' (1987), some of the engineers working on the company's products wondered whether it made sense to keep the animation group going at all.Price, p. 103 Pixar was losing money every year and Jobs was supporting the cash-strapped company through a line of credit with his personal guarantee.Price, p. 104 The engineers felt they were working hard to make money for Pixar while Lasseter's group was only spending it. Their passion was for building computers and software, not entertainment. Eventually, they discerned, to their chagrin, the reason why the company was supporting the division: the real priority of Catmull and Smith was to make films. The engineers were not alone in wondering about the value of Lasseter's short films. On repeated occasions in the late 1980s, Catmull barely dissuaded Jobs from shutting down the animation division due to financial constraints. At this same time, Jobs was clashing with Alvy Ray Smith, which would eventually lead to his resignation from Pixar after a heated argument during a meeting. Things were by no means well at the company and Lasseter and his team of animators knew this, and were afraid to ask for money to finance another short, which they storyboarded as ''Tin Toy''.{{cite book|last=Isaacson|first=Walter|title=[[Steve Jobs (book)|Steve Jobs]]|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|location=[[New York City|New York]]|year=2011|page=180|isbn=1-4516-4853-7}} ==Production== In the spring of 1988, cash was running so short that Jobs convened a meeting to decree deep spending cuts across the board. When it was over, Lasseter and his animation group were almost too afraid to ask Jobs about authorizing some extra money for another short. Finally, they broached the topic and Jobs sat silent, looking skeptical. The short would require close to $300,000 more out of his pocket. After a few minutes, he asked if there were any storyboards. Catmull took him down to the animation offices, and Lasseter started his show. With the storyboards pinned on his wall, Lasseter did the voices and acted out the shots—just as story men had done on the Disney lot for decades—and thereby showed his passion for the project. The stakes here were much higher than before, however. [[Ralph Guggenheim]], manager of the animation unit, recalled, "We knew that he wasn't just pitching for the film, he was pitching for the survival of the group."{{cite web | url=http://jimhillmedia.com/editor_in_chief1/b/jim_hill/archive/2008/08/01/i-can-go-to-disney-and-be-a-director-or-i-can-stay-here-and-make-history.aspx | title=I can go to Disney and be a director, or I can stay here and make history | publisher=JimHillMedia.com | date=July 31, 2008 | accessdate=March 5, 2012 | author=Hill, Jim}} Jobs warmed up to the project and agreed to provide the money. "I believed in what John was doing," Jobs later said. "It was art. He cared, and I cared. I always said yes." His only comment at the end of Lasseter’s presentation was, "All I ask of you, John, is to make it great."{{cite book|last=Isaacson|first=Walter|title=[[Steve Jobs (book)|Steve Jobs]]|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|location=[[New York City|New York]]|year=2011|page=181|isbn=1-4516-4853-7}} [[File:John Lasseter 2 cropped 2009.jpg|thumb|John Lasseter at the [[Venice Film Festival]] in [[66th Venice International Film Festival|2009]].]] That fall, after completion of ''Red's Dream'', most members of the company gathered at [[Stillwater Cove]], near [[Fort Ross]], to design a new software that was designed completely for the work of an animator.{{citation|title=Amidi|page= 24}} From the meeting came Menv software ("modeling Environment"), the first program specifically designed to facilitate the workflow of an animator, separating the various phases of the animation ([[Computer simulation|modeling]], [[animation]] and [[lighting]]), later renamed ''Puppets''.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3-8C1x4tXAQ|title=The Pixar Shorts: A Short History}} 0:06:32 [[Walt Disney Pictures]] To show the application of the new program, it was approved the production of a short. Inspired by the birth of his daughter Julia, [[William Reeves (animator)|William Reeves]] proposed the idea to create a human baby. Lasseter had an inspiration for the new opera based on the observation of his nephew, intent to put any toy in the mouth on the way. Lasseter said "In terms of toys the child must have seemed a terrible monster!"Price, p. 305 The story was about Lasseter’s love, classic toys, and was inspired by a visit made in 1987 at the Tin Toy Museum in [[Yokohama, Japan]]."Audio commentary to the short Tin Toy". [[John Lasseter]]{{cite book | title=Amidi | pages=23}} It was told from the perspective of a toy one-man band named Tinny, who meets a baby that charms and terrorizes him. Escaping under the couch, Tinny finds other frightened toys, but when the baby hits his head and cries, Tinny goes back out to cheer him up. ''Tin Toy'' was inspired much like ''Luxo Jr.'', namely, Lasseter's observations of a friend's baby. This time, he opted for a more ambitious task, attempting to mimic a human baby in its appearance, the movement of its arms, and its fickle moods. The film was officially a test of the [[PhotoRealistic RenderMan]] software.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IToEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT20&lpg=PT20&dq=%22tin+toy%22+pixar+%22PhotoRealistic+RenderMan%22&source=bl&ots=Ubj9MXhEVM&sig=8jWCVxSyjWC0mK8eAozIYb_raBM&hl=en&ei=qH9fTJyaIoScOJbNmb0J&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBEQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=%22tin%20toy%22%20pixar%20%22PhotoRealistic%20RenderMan%22&f=false |title=InfoWorld - 27 Feb 1989 |publisher=Books.google.com |date=1989-02-27 |accessdate=2010-10-12}} This was the only Pixar short rendered on the RM-1, a RenderMan specific computer that was never sold to the public.{{cite web |url=http://wiki.cgsociety.org/index.php/Renderman |title=Renderman - CGWiki |publisher=Wiki.cgsociety.org |date=2006-10-24 |accessdate=2010-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120721100705/http://wiki.cgsociety.org/index.php/Renderman |archivedate=2012-07-21 |df= }}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3jM5EZC1rs4C&pg=PA509&lpg=PA509&dq=tin+toy+pixar+%22rm-1%22+machine&source=bl&ots=Tkf9VoN8FT&sig=gCwg7wXi_yPg3WcJKix5ae2f_fE&hl=en&ei=73tfTLKUEt6gOPef9LwJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CCgQ6AEwBQ |title=Advanced RenderMan: creating CGI for motion pictures |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2010-10-12}} As with ''Luxo Jr.'' and ''Red's Dream'', it was also a chance for Lasseter to one-up his earlier efforts, taking his animation and storytelling to another level. The baby proved difficult to model and animate; "it just became an incredible burden," remembered Flip Phillips, a new member of the team at the time. In early attempts at a model of the baby's head, he appeared to have the face of a middle-aged man. The final version of the baby (known to the team as Billy) had a much-improved face with 40 separate facial muscles,[https://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/04/business/pixar-opens-horizons-for-pluto-dumbo-et-al.html?pagewanted=all Pixar Opens Horizons for Pluto, Dumbo et al. - NYTimes.com] but his skin had the look of plastic. When he moved, moreover, his body lacked the natural give of baby fat and his diaper had the solidity of cement—compromises made necessary by lack of time and the still-developing technology.Price, p. 105 The picture on the table is a photograph of director John Lasseter.Price, David A. (2008). ''[https://www.amazon.com/Pixar-Touch-Making-Company/dp/0307265757/ The Pixar Touch]''. P. 105. New York, Alfred A. Knopf ==Release== Lasseter and his technical directors slept under their desks at times to get ''Tin Toy'' finished before SIGGRAPH in [[Atlanta]] in August 1988, but to no avail. What the SIGGRAPH audience saw was the first three-fifths or so of the film, ending a cliffhanger moment with Tinny running into his box and watching in horror through the box's cellophane as Billy advances towards him. "Even though it wasn't complete, people were wowed by it," producer Ralph Guggenheim remembered. The audience of scientists and engineers to which it was shown at SIGGRAPH greeted it with a standing ovation. These praises were joined over the years, positive assessments of public and critics, who praised the innovation and technology in it. Luke Bonanno called it "One of the best Pixar short films,"{{cite web | url=http://www.dvdizzy.com/pixarshorts-vol1.html | title=Pixar Short Films Collection, Volume 1 | publisher=dvdizzy.com | date=November 2007 | accessdate=March 6, 2012 | author=Bonanno, Luke}} while other critics wrote that the film was "A fascinating glimpse of a fledgling art form."{{cite web | url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/pixarcollection1.php | title=Pixar Short Films Collection: Volume 1 | publisher=DVD Verdict | date=December 3, 2007 | accessdate=March 6, 2012 | author=Adam Arseneau, Judge | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130000039/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/pixarcollection1.php | archivedate=January 30, 2012 | df= }} and many praised the ability to move in just a few minutes and have been able to "encompass the full range of emotions you feel when a toy is used by a child."{{cite web | url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/pixarshortsbluray.php | title=Pixar Short Films Collection: Volume 1 (Blu-Ray) | publisher=DVD Verdict | date=February 2, 2008 | accessdate=March 6, 2012 | author=Michael Stailey | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127104039/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/pixarshortsbluray.php | archivedate=January 27, 2012 | df= }} Some criticisms were leveled at the character of Billy, who was called "the most frightening and disturbing piece of animation in the history of this art form." Dario Floreano stated that the [[uncanny valley]] concept was taken seriously by the film industry because of negative audience reactions to Billy.{{cite web | url=http://www.unexplainable.net/artman/publish/article_13844.shtml | title=Cattle Rustlin' in the Uncanny Valley | date=September 29, 2009 | accessdate=March 6, 2012 | author=Capps, Chris}} It is unknown when this short was first released in its entirety. ''Tin Toy'' went on to take the [[Academy Award]] for [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film|Best Animated Short]] in 1989 at the [[61st Academy Awards]] and was the first computer generated animated short film to receive an Oscar. With the award, ''Tin Toy'' went far to establish computer animation as a legitimate artistic medium outside SIGGRAPH and the animation-festival film circuit.Price, p. 106 A member of the Academy's board of governors, animator William Littlejohn, saw in ''Tin Toy'' a window into the potential of the young medium. "There is a realism that's rather astonishing," he told ''[[The New York Times]]''. "It emulates photography, but with artistic staging." Robert Winquist, head of the character animation program at [[CalArts]], went farther, predicting that computer animation was "going to take over in a short time." He publicly advised animators, "Put down your pencil and your paintbrush and do it another way." The short was selected for preservation in the United States [[National Film Registry]] by the [[Library of Congress]] as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" in 2003. ===Academy Award=== 1988 - [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film|Best Animated Short Film]] ===Other awards=== 1989 - [[Seattle International Film Festival]] - Best Short Film
1989 - World Animation Celebration - Best Computer-Assisted Animation
2003 - [[National Film Registry]] ==Merchandising== Apart from the home video editions of the short film, ''Tin Toy'' was not the subject of any type of merchandise, like all the other short films produced by the company. The only exception is the reproduction of vinyl Tinny, produced by MINDStyle in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.mindstyle.com/blog/?p=3950|title=The Art Of Pixar|publisher=MINDstyle|date=August 2, 2010}} Pixar, in fact, sold the license to the manufacturer of ''Tin Toy'' MINDStyle objects, which created a marquette of the vinyl character Tinny inside of the line Art Toy Collectible limited Edition of 500 pieces, the price of ninety dollars. The box, which is a faithful reproduction of the packaging of the toy view in short, in addition to containing the model of Tinny, presents a certificate of authenticity printed on a card showing the storyboard in pencil of a scene from the short.{{cite web|url=http://www.mwctoys.com/REVIEW_081110a.htm|title=Pixar's Tin Toy MINDStyle|publisher=Captain Toy}} ==Scrapped sequel== In the early 1990s, Pixar began to make arrangements with Disney to produce the first computer-animated film. The project went through, but considering the abrupt transition from shorts to feature a few minutes to an hour and a half, Pixar set out to create a special half-hour to see if they could manage a production that was similar to that of an actual film. Driven by the victory at the Oscars that year, a sequel to ''Tin Toy'' called "A Tin Toy Christmas," was originally planned as a half-hour-long television special to be used to convince film studios that Pixar was capable of producing a feature film. This idea was brought to the table at the initial talks with Disney for ''[[Toy Story]]''. The basic idea was that Tinny was part of a set of toy players who are not successful and remain unsold for years. Separated from other components, Tinny ends up by mistake in a toy shop of our age where he meets several characters, including a soft pink bear named Lotso.{{cite web | url=http://jimhillmedia.com/editor_in_chief1/b/jim_hill/archive/2007/12/14/tube-thursday-the-pixar-holiday-special-you-never-got-to-see-tin-toy-christmas.aspx | title=The Pixar TV special you never got to see, "A Tin Toy Christmas" | publisher=JimHillMedia.com | date=December 14, 2007 | accessdate=March 6, 2012 | author=Hill, Jim}}{{cite web | url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/toy_story_3/news/1888969/2/its_toy_hell_says_toy_story_3_director/ | title=It's Toy Hell, Says Toy Story 3 Director. | publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | date=June 18, 2010 | accessdate=March 6, 2012}} The project was abandoned because the television network that would have produced it could not afford the fees required (according to director [[Pete Docter]], the special would have required a sum of eighteen times higher than the allowed budget). Disney was uninterested in the concept and urged Pixar to produce a feature immediately, which became a critical and commercial success.''To Infinity and Beyond!: The Story of Pixar Animation Studios'' The character of Lotso, however, was adapted for the [[Toy Story 3|third installment]] of the [[Toy Story (franchise)|''Toy Story'' series]]. ==See also== *''[[Toy Story]]'' (1995), Pixar's first computer-animated feature film which grew out of a ''Tin Toy'' sequel. ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== * {{cite book|last=Price|first=David|year=2008|title=The Pixar Touch | location=New York| publisher=Alfred A. Knopf| isbn=0-307-26575-7|ref=Price}} ==External links== * {{Official website|https://www.pixar.com/tin-toy}} * {{IMDb title|id=0096273|title=Tin Toy}} * {{tcmdb title|502252|Tin Toy}} * {{bcdb title|id=38949|title=Tin Toy}} {{Pixar Animation Studios}} {{Toy Story}} {{John Lasseter}} {{AcademyAwardBestAnimatedShortFilm 1981–2000}} [[Category:1988 films]] [[Category:1988 animated films]] [[Category:1980s American animated films]] [[Category:1980s animated short films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Best Animated Short Academy Award winners]] [[Category:Short films directed by John Lasseter]] [[Category:Films without speech]] [[Category:Pixar short films]] [[Category:Screenplays by John Lasseter]] [[Category:Toy Story]] [[Category:United States National Film Registry films]] [[Category:Films about toys]] [[Category:Toys in fiction]]

'''Vatsun''' is derived from Sanskrit ‘Vachan’ meaning word/speech. This is because it has no particular pattern of versification or rhyme scheme.<ref>Ayyappapanicker, K. and Sahitya Akademi ''Medieval Indian Literature: An Anthology.'' 1997.</ref> The metres and rhyme schemes of vatsun are varied, but generally each unit is a stanza of three lines followed by a refrain (vooj). Vatsun bears a resemblance to [[Urdu|Urdu lyric]]. Vatsun is also similar to the [[ghazal]]s of the Middle East and [[iambic pentameter]] of the Western world.
In poetry it is a popular age-old folk-form dating back to the fourteenth century, when [[Lal Ded]] and Hazart Sheikh-ul-Alam (alias [[Nund Reshi|Nund Rishi]]) wrote in Kashmiri language the devotional poetry depicting their mystic experiences, love for God, love for others, and folk dancing.<ref>"Vatsun." ''Encyclopaedia of Indian literature vol. 5.'' 1992.</ref><ref>Koul, Omkar N. ''Kashmiri Language, Linguistics, and Culture.'' Central Institute of Indian Languages: Manasagangotri. 200.</ref>
== Notable Vatsun poets == *[[Lal Ded]] (1320–1387) * [[Nund Rishi]] (1377–1438) *[[ Naima Saab]] (1800–1880) * [[Dina Nath Nadim]] (1916–1988)
== See also == *[[ghazal]] *[[Iambic Pentameter]]
